channel.title: NYT > U.S. News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2020 The New York Times Company

item.title: George Floyd Updates: Buildings Ablaze in Minneapolis as Protests Continue Nationwide
item.description: Derek Chauvin, a white former police officer, was charged with murder days after using his knee to pin down George Floyd, a black man who later died.
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: A protester wiped a tear from another during a demonstration in Minneapolis on Friday.

item.title: Twitter Places Warning on Trump Minneapolis Tweet, Saying It Glorified Violence
item.description: Twitter said the tweets, which implied that protesters in Minneapolis could be shot, glorified violence — the first time it had applied such warnings to any public figure’s posts.
item.dc:creator: Davey Alba, Kate Conger and Raymond Zhong
item.media:description: President Trump on Thursday signed an executive order meant to limit social media companies’ legal protections against liability claims.

item.title: Sparring and Schedules Offer Glimpse of Pandemic’s Partisan Lens
item.description: The White House directly challenges the House’s new rules. President Trump plans to resume in-person fund-raising soon. New York City, Washington and Los Angeles plan to lift some restrictions.
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: John Howard, director of the National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health, testified before a House committee on Thursday.

item.title: George Floyd Death: How the Knee-on-Neck Hold Resulted in Tragedy
item.description: Police departments have tried to ban or severely limit the use of chokeholds and neck restraints. But in Minneapolis, a knee pressing on a neck led to a man’s death.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar
item.media:credit: Jenn Ackerman for The New York Times
item.media:description: A mural of George Floyd in Minneapolis. The Minneapolis Police Department manual states that neck restraints are basically reserved for when an officer feels caught in a life or death situation, which did not appear to be the case in Mr. Floyd’s detention.

item.title: Live Coronavirus Updates
item.description: Reopening plans will affect the fight against climate change. President Trump said the United States would end its relationship with the W.H.O.
item.media:credit: Sarah Blesener for The New York Times
item.media:description: Domino Park in Brooklyn on Monday.

item.title: What Time Is the SpaceX Launch? How to Watch
item.description: What you need to know about the mission taking two NASA astronauts to the space station on Saturday.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: Will Saturday be the day?

item.title: Atlanta Protesters Clash With Police as Mayor Warns ‘You Are Disgracing Our City’
item.description: Protesters broke windows and set fire to cars after the death of George Floyd in Minneapolis. Protests emerged in many U.S. cities.
item.dc:creator: Richard Fausset and Michael Levenson
item.media:credit: Alyssa Pointer/Atlanta Journal-Constitution, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A police car burned after protesters marched to the Georgia State Capitol on Friday.

item.title: Flynn Discussed Sanctions at Length With Russian Diplomat, Transcripts Show
item.description: The former national security adviser now says he does not remember those discussions as he fights a criminal charge he had previously pleaded guilty to.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes, Adam Goldman and Nicholas Fandos
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods
item.media:description: The transcripts show that the sanctions were the central discussion point in the calls between Michael T. Flynn and the Russian ambassador.

item.title: Read the Criminal Complaint Against Derek Chauvin
item.description: A statement of probable cause used to support charges against a former Minneapolis police officer detailed the minutes before Mr. Floyd’s death.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Mervosh
item.media:credit: Darnella Frazier, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A still image taken from a video, courtesy of Darnella Frazier via Facebook, showed Derek Chauvin, a Minneapolis officer, during the arrest of George Floyd.

item.title: Derek Chauvin Charged in Death of George Floyd in Minneapolis
item.description: City officials on Friday were urging calm the day after protests turned violent and a police precinct went up in flames.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar, Tim Arango and Manny Fernandez
item.media:description: A building burned in Minneapolis on Thursday night as protests continued following the death of George Floyd.

item.title: How Two Co-Workers, a Fake Bill and an Encounter Roiled a Nation
item.description: The episode began with a report of a $20 counterfeit bill. It ended in a fatal encounter with the police, which the authorities have described in detail for the first time.
item.dc:creator: Matt Furber, Audra D. S. Burch and Frances Robles
item.media:credit: Jenn Ackerman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters lined up opposite members of the police near the home of Derek Chauvin, a former Minneapolis police officer, in Oakdale, Minn., on Thursday.

item.title: A Justice Dept. Skeptical of Police Abuse Cases Vows to Investigate Floyd Death
item.description: Critics pointed to the president’s and the attorney general’s full-throated support for the police and the department’s inaction on systemic policing issues.
item.dc:creator: Katie Benner and Emily Badger
item.media:description: Civil justice advocates are wary of the Justice Department’s involvement in the Floyd case.

item.title: Congress Plans Hearings on Racial Violence and Use of Force by the Police
item.description: A top Democrat said the House would likely weigh a federal chokehold ban as leaders in the House and Senate announced hearings on race and policing.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Fandos
item.media:credit: Kirsten Luce for The New York Times
item.media:description: Officers arresting a protester on Friday in New York before a demonstration against police violence.

item.title: ‘The Pain Is Too Intense’: Joe Biden Challenges White Americans
item.description: In his first formal remarks on the death of a black Minneapolis man, Joseph Biden spoke in stark terms about the everyday indignities African-Americans still suffer.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Martin and Katie Glueck

item.title: Over Veterans’ Protests, Trump Vetoes Measure to Block Student Loan Rules
item.description: President Trump sided with Education Secretary Betsy DeVos over veterans’ groups, vetoing a measure that would have blocked new regulations that tighten access to student loan forgiveness.
item.dc:creator: Erica L. Green
item.media:description: Betsy DeVos, the education secretary, this month during a cabinet meeting at the White House.

item.title: Blaming China for Pandemic, Trump Says U.S. Will Leave the W.H.O.
item.description: America’s decades-long relationship with the organization has been instrumental in improving health around the world.
item.dc:creator: Donald G. McNeil Jr. and Andrew Jacobs
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: President Trump made the announcement Friday in the Rose Garden.

item.title: Their Minneapolis Restaurant Burned, but They Back the Protest
item.description: Though a Bangladeshi family lost their business in the uproar over the death of George Floyd, they support demonstrators and helped medics treat them.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg

item.title: Army Withdraws Nomination for Officer Involved in Deadly Niger Ambush
item.description: The decision comes amid criticism that the American military is harsher in dispensing punishment to African-American officers than to their white counterparts.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper and Thomas Gibbons-Neff
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
United States Army Special Forces (Green Berets)
item.media:credit: Tara Todras-Whitehill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Col. Bradley D. Moses, left, is the only officer involved in the episode who had escaped some form of punishment so far for the fatal ambush in Niger.

item.title: While Twitter Confronts Trump, Zuckerberg Keeps Facebook Out of It
item.description: The companies have similar policies on the limits of what they allow users to post. But Facebook is more permissive when the user is President Trump.
item.dc:creator: Mike Isaac and Cecilia Kang
item.media:credit: From left: Eric Thayer for The New York Times; Tom Brenner/The New York Times
item.media:description: Twitter’s Jack Dorsey and Facebook’s Mark Zuckerberg have taken very different approaches to some of President Trump’s posts this week.

item.title: What Trump, Biden and Obama Said About the Death of George Floyd
item.description: Both President Trump and Joseph R. Biden Jr. have called for justice for Mr. Floyd. Mr. Trump has also called protesters “thugs,” and Mr. Biden has blamed him for “incendiary tweets.”
item.dc:creator: Maggie Astor
item.media:description: President Trump addressed George Floyd’s death at the start of a round table discussion with executives.

item.title: It’s Not Whether You Were Exposed to the Coronavirus. It’s How Much.
item.description: The pathogen is proving a familiar adage: The dose makes the poison.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Misha Friedman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Harry Henri, a research assistant, working with blood samples from coronavirus patients at SUNY Downstate’s BioBank in Brooklyn.

item.title: Charges Recommended Against 3 Officers Involved in Violent N.Y. Arrest
item.description: The departmental charges would be in connection with a May 2 incident in the East Village during which an officer sat on a man’s neck.
item.dc:creator: Ashley Southall and Jeffery C. Mays
item.media:description: In early May, Officer Francisco X. Garcia put his full weight on the upper torso and neck of Donni Wright, who had objected to the arrest of two other people.

item.title: Economic Giants Are Restarting. Here’s What It Means for Climate Change.
item.description: Want to know whether the world can avert catastrophe? Watch the recovery plans coming out now in Europe, China and the United States.
item.dc:creator: Somini Sengupta
item.media:description: A demonstrator in Abuja, Nigeria, on a day of global climate strikes in September.

item.title: Senior Interior Official Broke Ethics Rules a 2nd Time, Watchdog Says
item.description: An assistant secretary at the department used his position to help a family member get a job at the Environmental Protection Agency, according to an internal government investigation.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.media:description: Douglas W. Domenech, an assistant interior secretary, in 2010.

item.title: Mayor Jacob Frey of Minneapolis Had Promised to Improve Police Relations
item.description: The mayor took the helm of the city after fatal police shootings hampered his predecessor.
item.dc:creator: Farah Stockman
item.media:credit: Elizabeth Flores/Star Tribune, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Mayor Jacob Frey of Minneapolis spoke during a news conference on Thursday.

item.title: Congress Calls State Dept. Officials for Interviews in Expanded Pompeo Inquiry
item.description: Lawmakers are investigating whether Secretary of State Mike Pompeo urged President Trump to fire Steve A. Linick, the department’s inspector general, to shield himself from Mr. Linick’s inquiries.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.category: United States Office of Special Counsel
item.media:description: Secretary of State Mike Pompeo urged the ouster of Steve A. Linick, who was the State Department inspector general.

item.title: Who is Tim Walz? Minnesota Governor Appeals for Healing
item.description: The governor, a Democrat, is a former member of the National Guard who deployed the force after the killing of George Floyd.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Mazzei
item.media:credit: Evan Frost/Minnesota Public Radio, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Gov. Tim Walz during a news conference at the Department of Public Safety in St. Paul, Minn., last weekend.

item.title: Trump's Remark About Shooting Looters Dates Back to 1960s Racial Unrest
item.description: The phrase the president tweeted, “When the looting starts, the shooting starts,” was used by a Miami police chief widely condemned by civil rights groups.
item.dc:creator: Michael Wines
item.category: National Assn for the Advancement of Colored People
item.media:description: Twitter placed a warning on President Trump’s tweet, saying it glorified violence.

item.title: Protests in Minnesota Renew Scrutiny of Klobuchar’s Record as Prosecutor
item.description: Amy Klobuchar, now being considered as a potential vice-presidential candidate, oversaw several cases involving police shootings in Minneapolis during her years as a prosecutor.
item.dc:creator: Nick Corasaniti and Katie Glueck
item.category: National Assn for the Advancement of Colored People
item.media:credit: T.J. Kirkpatrick for The New York Times
item.media:description: Amy Klobuchar served as the Hennepin County, Minn., prosecutor before being elected to the Senate in 2006.

item.title: Scientists Question Major Hydroxychloroquine Study
item.description: Experts demanded verification of data and methods used in a study of drugs to treat Covid-19. The study suggested the drugs might have increased deaths.
item.dc:creator: Roni Caryn Rabin
item.media:description: The drug hydroxychloroquine, promoted by President Trump and others in recent months as a possible treatment for people infected with the coronavirus.

item.title: How Trump's Twitter Remarks Escalate Growing Crisis in Minneapolis
item.description: The president’s tweets prompted Twitter to append them with a note saying the posts were “glorifying violence.” Joe Biden condemned Mr. Trump, saying “it’s no time to encourage violence.”
item.dc:creator: Maggie Haberman and Alexander Burns
item.media:description: President Trump issued the threat in a string of tweets around 1 a.m. on Friday.

item.title: Recipe Ideas: How to Use Your California Produce
item.description: Friday: Some expert advice from Los Angeles. Also: More reopening updates.
item.dc:creator: Jill Cowan and Tejal Rao
item.media:description: Nick Sari offered his products to a shopper at the West L.A. Farmer's Market earlier this month.

item.title: When Voters Discuss Coronavirus, They’re Really Talking About Trump
item.description: Even though most people don’t name the coronavirus as their top voting issue, President Trump’s response to the outbreak, and how it’s perceived, will probably swing the election.
item.dc:creator: Giovanni Russonello
item.media:description: Even among Republicans, approval of President Trump’s handling of the virus now runs a few percentage points behind their rating of his overall performance as president.

item.title: Protests Against Police Escalate
item.description: And what else you need to know today.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: Protesters outside the burning 3rd Police Precinct in Minneapolis Thursday.

item.title: President Trump Versus Twitter and Social Media
item.description: President Trump’s taking aim at Twitter for fact-checking his tweets is part of a long tradition upheld by aggrieved internet trolls. The stakes are high.
item.dc:creator: Kevin Roose
item.media:description: On Thursday, President Trump issued an executive order threatening to remove legal protections that shield tech companies from liability for what gets posted on their platforms.

item.title: Stocks Climb After Trump Speaks on China
item.description: The latest on stock market and business news during the coronavirus outbreak.
item.media:description: Fed Chair Jerome Powell in March.

item.title: No Touch, No Hands-On Learning, for Now, as Museums Try to Reopen
item.description: Science and children’s museums are studying how to rethink their many tactile exhibits to keep people safe.
item.dc:creator: Julia Jacobs
item.category: Natural History Museum of Los Angeles County
Strong National Museum of Play (Rochester, NY)

item.title: How Trump’s Tweets Cause Collateral Damage for Families Already in Pain
item.description: The president’s baseless insinuations about the death of Lori Klausutis reflect a callous pattern that can leave even ordinary people facing threats from his supporters long after he has moved on.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Mazzei, Jennifer Medina, Maggie Haberman and Sydney Ember
item.media:description: President Trump has pushed conspiracy theories for years to draw public attention, create distractions and try to damage opponents and policies.

item.title: Border Wall Land Grabs Accelerate as Owners Shelter From Pandemic
item.description: With private property proving hard to acquire, the administration has stepped up efforts to secure land on the Mexican border for President Trump’s wall.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.media:credit: Alyssa Schukar for The New York Times
item.media:description: A section of the border wall under construction near Donna, Texas, last year.

item.title: Pandemic Forces Car Dealers to Do the Unthinkable: Sell Online
item.description: Dealerships have long resisted e-commerce, but with many showrooms closed, the dynamic is changing.
item.dc:creator: Neal E. Boudette
item.media:credit: Andrew Seng for The New York Times
item.media:description: John Santiago of Paragon Honda in Queens prepares a car for delivery. The dealership’s online sales have surged since the coronavirus outbreak.

item.title: The Birds Are Not on Lockdown, and More People Are Watching Them
item.description: Bird-watching has surged in popularity during the pandemic. It’s easy to start, and you can do it anywhere — even from inside, and even in urban spaces.
item.dc:creator: Jacey Fortin
item.media:description: “What is that thing?”

item.title: As Day Care Centers Reopen, Will Parents Send Their Children?
item.description: Reopening requires cash, safety renovations and parental confidence — all of which are in short supply.
item.dc:creator: Dana Goldstein and Julie Bosman
item.media:credit: Christopher Capozziello for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tennille Smalls runs a child care center out of her home in New Haven, Conn. Her business is hanging on, but only precariously.

item.title: Minneapolis Precinct Fire: How a Night of Chaos Unfolded
item.description: Videographers for The Times captured the scene outside the Third Precinct in Minneapolis as peaceful demonstrations over the death of George Floyd turned violent, and a group of protesters set the building on fire.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Kerr, Mike Shum, Katie G. Nelson, Dmitriy Khavin and Haley Willis

item.title: 7 People Shot at Louisville Protest Over the Death of Breonna Taylor
item.description: The protests in Kentucky were prompted by the killing of Ms. Taylor, a black woman who was shot dead by white police officers who entered her home in March.
item.dc:creator: Mike Baker
item.media:description: A demonstration protesting the death of Breonna Taylor in Louisville, Ky., escalated on Thursday night, and seven people were shot. The police said it was too early to determine who did the shooting.
